title: Google Cloud Run with gunicorn/flask - getting intermittent 504s
text: I run a Flask application on Cloud Run with gunicorn and worker type gthread. On low level, this API just writes/retrieves entries from Datastore and Pubsub so all operations are light. The traffic is 20,000 requests a day with max QPS 20 requests and average QPS 2Every few days/weeks, a portion of traffic (25%-50%) gets a 504 response with the following error:After a few hours, the issue resolves itself (redeploying the app or a new CR instance kicking in solves it instantly). Those 504 requests don't seem to even reach the application. This error does not seem to be linked to any errors in stderr, stdout or increases in QPS. I've set up some advanced logging and cloud profiler but I don't get any useful information. This application ran perfectly fine on App Engine with gunicorn sync worker. The only difference is gunicorn settings. Sync worker worked very slow on CR so I used gthread instead.Any ideas where to look next?Dockerfileapp.pygcloud deploy command:

title: How to raise an error in graceful way in celery workflows?
text:
I have a celery workflow of chains and groups designed in a way such that if a particular task fails, other linked tasks are not run.I have try/except block in the first_task to handle exceptions.
If the first_task ends in an error and goes inside the except, celery considers that as a successful execution and still runs chained_task. Only if I have a  statement in the except block the chained_task is not executed but that leaves ugly traceback in the console.Is there any way to graceful way to handle exceptions and still return an error from a function so that celery doesn't execute the 2nd task?

title: In a Windows7 environment, the installation of jupyter in Pycharm was unsuccessful
text:
In order to use Jupyter Notebook,in the terminal of Pycharm,The first step is direct installation：
pip install Jupyter
and then:
jupyter notebook
The following error message appears:Traceback (most recent call last):
File "d:\soft setup\python\lib\runpy.py", line 174, in _run_module_as_main
"", fname, loader, pkg_name)File "d:\soft setup\python\lib\runpy.py", line 72, in _run_code
exec code in run_globalsFile "D:\soft setup\python\Scripts\jupyter.exe__.py", line 9, in File "d:\soft setup\python\lib\site-packages\jupyter_core\command.py", line 186, in main
_execvp(command, sys.argv[1:])File "d:\soft setup\python\lib\site-packages\jupyter_core\command.py", line 104, in _execvpraise OSError('%r not found' % cmd, errno.ENOENT)
OSError: [Errno 'jupyter-notebook' not found] 2I tried to increase the environment variable of the computer:
"d:\soft setup\python\lib\site-packages"
This method doesn't work,the error message is the same as above!I tried a different solution online:
pip install --upgrade --force-reinstall --no-cache-dir jupyter
and then:
jupyter notebook
This method doesn't work,the error message is the same as above!I can know from the error message, I should be installed successfully jupyter Notebook, but why can't it start?
author: dengm155

title: How can I get Visual Studio to run using the environment I've selected?
text: First of all, I am extremely new to Python and not formally trained in computer science, so I apologize if some of my terminology is incorrect or missing.As background information, there are 3 main environments I have been testing, IronPython 2.7 (no numpy), Python 2.7 (numpy installed), and Python 3.7 (no numpy installed).Regardless of the environment I choose from the drop-down list, Visual Studio will seemingly only run using the Python 3.7 environment. I've tested with simple lines such as "import numpy" and "print 'Hello world'", and regardless of the environments I've chosen and the packages installed for each, I always get errors which indicate it's using the Python 3.7 environment (numpy package not installed, print statement requires parentheses around the argument).However, when I use the interactive window, it respects the selected environment for the interactive window, and produces the expected results. This even transfers when selecting the environment of the folder containing my script, which matches the environment I've chosen in the main window. It is only when using the "Start project" option that it seems to force into using Python 3.7.For further information, my original script had been completely functional, and was written to interface with another software, but then there was a deep, multi-week update to the software (and potentially other things, I was only informed about the status of the software) and ever since then it has been non-functional due to this forced use of Python 3.7.Can anyone tell me why Visual Studio is doing this? How can I get Visual Studio to respect the chosen environment?
author: kkoll
